# Invasion of Normandy

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the first few weeks of the invasion of Normandy. The
first day of the landings (commonly known as D-Day) is covered in more detail
at [Normandy landings](/wiki/Normandy_landings "Normandy landings").

For earlier invasions of Normandy in other wars, see [Invasions of Normandy
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Invasions_of_Normandy_\(disambiguation\) "Invasions of
Normandy \(disambiguation\)").

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Merge-arrows.svg/50px-Merge-arrows.svg.png) |  It has been suggested that this article be [merged](/wiki/Wikipedia:Merging "Wikipedia:Merging") with _[Operation Overlord](/wiki/Operation_Overlord "Operation Overlord")_. ([Discuss](/wiki/Talk:Invasion_of_Normandy#Merger_proposals "Talk:Invasion of Normandy")) _Proposed since December 2016._

Part of [Operation Overlord](/wiki/Operation_Overlord "Operation Overlord")
([World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"))  
[![Into the Jaws of Death 23-0455M
edit.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Into_the_Jaws_of_Death_23-0455M_edit.jpg/300px-
Into_the_Jaws_of_Death_23-0455M_edit.jpg)](/wiki/File:Into_the_Jaws_of_Death_23-0455M_edit.jpg)  
_[Into the Jaws of Death](/wiki/Into_the_Jaws_of_Death "Into the Jaws of
Death")_ by [Robert F. Sargent](/wiki/Robert_F._Sargent "Robert F. Sargent").
Assault craft land one of the first waves at [Omaha Beach](/wiki/Omaha_Beach
"Omaha Beach"). The [U.S. Coast Guard](/wiki/United_States_Coast_Guard "United
States Coast Guard") caption identifies the unit as Company E, [16th
Infantry](/wiki/16th_Infantry_Regiment_\(United_States\) "16th Infantry
Regiment \(United States\)"), [1st Infantry
Division](/wiki/1st_Infantry_Division_\(United_States\) "1st Infantry Division
\(United States\)").  
| Date | 6 June 1944 – mid-July 1944

The [Western Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") of
[World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") launched the largest
[amphibious invasion](/wiki/Amphibious_warfare "Amphibious warfare") in
history when they assaulted [Normandy](/wiki/Normandy "Normandy"), located on
the northern coast of France, on 6 June 1944. The invaders were able to
establish a [beachhead](/wiki/Beachhead "Beachhead") as part of [Operation
Overlord](/wiki/Operation_Overlord "Operation Overlord") after [a successful
"D-Day,"](/wiki/Normandy_landings "Normandy landings") the first day of the
invasion.

Allied land forces came from the [United States](/wiki/United_States_Army
"United States Army"), [Britain](/wiki/British_Army "British Army"),
[Canada](/wiki/Canadian_Army "Canadian Army"), and [Free French
forces](/wiki/Free_French_forces "Free French forces"). In the weeks following
the invasion, [Polish forces](/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces_in_the_West "Polish
Armed Forces in the West") and contingents from Belgium, Czechoslovakia,
Greece and the Netherlands participated in the ground campaign; most also
provided air and naval support alongside elements of the [Royal Australian Air
Force](/wiki/Royal_Australian_Air_Force "Royal Australian Air Force"), the
[Royal New Zealand Air Force](/wiki/Royal_New_Zealand_Air_Force "Royal New
Zealand Air Force"), and the [Royal Norwegian Navy](/wiki/Royal_Norwegian_Navy
"Royal Norwegian Navy").[5][nb 1][1]

The Normandy invasion began with overnight [parachute](/wiki/Paratrooper
"Paratrooper") and [glider](/wiki/Military_glider "Military glider") landings,
massive [air attacks](/wiki/Aerial_warfare "Aerial warfare") and [naval
bombardments](/wiki/Naval_gunfire_support "Naval gunfire support"). In the
early morning, [amphibious landings](/wiki/Amphibious_warfare "Amphibious
warfare") commenced on five beaches codenamed [Sword](/wiki/Sword_Beach "Sword
Beach"), [Juno](/wiki/Juno_Beach "Juno Beach"), [Gold](/wiki/Gold_Beach "Gold
Beach"), [Omaha](/wiki/Omaha_Beach "Omaha Beach") and [Utah](/wiki/Utah_Beach
"Utah Beach"), with troops from the United States landing on Omaha and Utah,
Great Britain landing on Gold and Sword and Canada landing on Juno. During the
evening the remaining elements of the airborne divisions landed. Land forces
used on D-Day sailed from bases along the south coast of England, the most
important of these being [Portsmouth](/wiki/Portsmouth "Portsmouth").[6]

##
Planning[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Planning")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Soldiers-english-
coast.jpg/220px-Soldiers-english-coast.jpg)](/wiki/File:Soldiers-english-
coast.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Soldiers-english-coast.jpg "Enlarge")

U.S. soldiers march through Weymouth, Dorset en route to board landing ships
for the invasion of France.

Allied forces rehearsed their D-Day roles for months before the invasion. On
28 April 1944, in south [Devon](/wiki/Devon "Devon") on the English coast, 749
U.S. soldiers and sailors were killed when [German torpedo boats](/wiki/E-boat
"E-boat") surprised one of these landing exercises, [Exercise
Tiger](/wiki/Exercise_Tiger "Exercise Tiger").[7]

In the months leading up to the invasion, the Allied forces conducted a
deception operation, [Operation Fortitude](/wiki/Operation_Fortitude
"Operation Fortitude"), aimed at misleading the Germans with respect to the
date and place of the invasion.

There were several leaks prior to or on D-Day. Through the [Cicero
affair](/wiki/Cicero_affair "Cicero affair"), the Germans obtained documents
containing references to Overlord, but these documents lacked all detail.[8]
[Double Cross](/wiki/Double_Cross_System "Double Cross System") agents, such
as the Spaniard [Juan Pujol](/wiki/Juan_Pujol_Garc%C3%ADa "Juan Pujol García")
(code-named Garbo), played an important role in convincing the German High
Command that Normandy was at best a diversionary attack. U.S. Major General
Henry Miller, chief supply officer of the US 9th Air Force, during a party at
[Claridge's](/wiki/Claridge%27s "Claridge's") Hotel in London complained to
guests of the supply problems he was having but that after the invasion, which
he told them would be before 15 June, supply would be easier. After being
told, Eisenhower reduced Miller to lieutenant colonel [Associated Press, June
10, 1944] and sent him back to the U.S. where he retired.[9] Another such leak
was General [Charles de Gaulle](/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle "Charles de Gaulle")'s
radio message after D-Day. He, unlike all the other leaders, stated that this
invasion was the real invasion. This had the potential to ruin the Allied
deceptions Fortitude North and Fortitude South. In contrast, [Gen.
Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight D. Eisenhower") referred to the
landings as the initial invasion.

Only ten days each month were suitable for launching the operation: a day near
the [full moon](/wiki/Full_moon "Full moon") was needed both for illumination
during the hours of darkness and for the [spring
tide](/wiki/Tide#Range_variation:_springs_and_neaps "Tide"), the former to
illuminate navigational landmarks for the crews of aircraft, gliders and
landing craft, and the latter to expose defensive obstacles placed by the
German forces in the surf on the seaward approaches to the beaches. A full
moon occurred on 6 June. [Allied Expeditionary Force Supreme
Commander](/wiki/Supreme_Headquarters_Allied_Expeditionary_Force "Supreme
Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force") Dwight D. Eisenhower had tentatively
selected 5 June as the date for the assault. The weather was fine during most
of May, but deteriorated in early June. On 4 June, conditions were clearly
unsuitable for a landing; wind and high seas would make it impossible to
launch landing craft from larger ships at sea, low clouds would prevent
aircraft finding their targets. The Allied troop convoys already at sea were
forced to take shelter in bays and inlets on the south coast of Britain for
the night.

It seemed possible that everything would have to be cancelled and the troops
returned to their embarkation camps (which would be almost impossible, as the
enormous movement of follow-up formations into them was already
proceeding).[10] The next full moon period would be nearly a month away. At a
vital meeting on 5 June, Eisenhower's chief meteorologist ([Group
Captain](/wiki/Group_Captain "Group Captain") [J.M. Stagg](/wiki/J.M._Stagg
"J.M. Stagg")) forecast a brief improvement for 6 June.[11] Commander of all
land forces for the invasion General Bernard Montgomery and Eisenhower's Chief
of Staff General [Walter Bedell Smith](/wiki/Walter_Bedell_Smith "Walter
Bedell Smith") wished to proceed with the invasion. Commander of the Allied
Air Forces [Air Chief Marshal](/wiki/Air_Chief_Marshal "Air Chief Marshal")
[Leigh Mallory](/wiki/Trafford_Leigh_Mallory "Trafford Leigh Mallory") was
doubtful, but Allied Naval Commander-in-Chief [Admiral](/wiki/Admiral
"Admiral") [Bertram Ramsay](/wiki/Bertram_Ramsay "Bertram Ramsay") believed
that conditions would be marginally favorable.[10] On the strength of Stagg's
forecast, Eisenhower ordered the invasion to proceed.[12] As a result,
prevailing overcast skies limited Allied air support, and no serious damage
would be done to the beach defences on Omaha and Juno.[13]

The Germans meanwhile took comfort from the existing poor conditions, which
were worse over Northern France than over the [English
Channel](/wiki/English_Channel "English Channel") itself, and believed no
invasion would be possible for several days. Some troops stood down and many
senior officers were away for the weekend. Field Marshal [Erwin
Rommel](/wiki/Erwin_Rommel "Erwin Rommel") took a few days' leave to celebrate
his wife's birthday,[14] while dozens of division, regimental and battalion
commanders were away from their posts conducting war games just prior to the
invasion.[15]

##
Codenames[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Codenames")]

The Allies assigned codenames to the various operations involved in the
invasion. _Overlord_ was the name assigned to the establishment of a large-
scale lodgement on the northern portion of the Continent. The first phase, the
establishment of a secure foothold, was codenamed _Neptune_. According to the
D-day museum:

    The armed forces use codenames to refer to the planning and execution of specific military operations. Operation Overlord was the codename for the Allied invasion of northwest Europe. The assault phase of Operation Overlord was known as Operation Neptune. (…) Operation Neptune began on D-Day (6 June 1944) and ended on 30 June 1944. By this time, the Allies had established a firm foothold in Normandy. Operation Overlord also began on D-Day, and continued until Allied forces crossed the [River Seine](/wiki/River_Seine "River Seine") on 19 August 1944.[16]

Officers with knowledge of D-Day were not to be sent where there was the
slightest danger of being captured. These officers were given the codename of
"[Bigot](/wiki/BIGOT_list "BIGOT list")", derived from the words "To Gib" (To
[Gibraltar](/wiki/Gibraltar "Gibraltar")) that was stamped on the papers of
officers who took part in the [North African](/wiki/North_Africa "North
Africa") invasion in 1942.[17] On the night of 27 April, during [Exercise
Tiger](/wiki/Exercise_Tiger "Exercise Tiger"), a pre-invasion exercise off the
coast of [Slapton Sands](/wiki/Slapton,_Devon "Slapton, Devon") beach, several
American [LSTs](/wiki/Tank_Landing_Ship "Tank Landing Ship") were attacked by
German [E boats](/wiki/E_boats "E boats") and among the 638 Americans killed
in the attack and a further 308 killed by friendly fire, ten "Bigots" were
listed as missing. As the invasion would be cancelled if any were captured or
unaccounted for[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_], their fate was given the highest priority and
eventually all ten bodies were recovered.

### D-Day[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: D-Day")]

The following major units were landed on D-Day (6 June 1944). A more detailed
order of battle for D-Day itself can be found at [Normandy
landings](/wiki/Normandy_landings#Allied_order_of_battle "Normandy landings")
and [List of Allied forces in the Normandy
Campaign](/wiki/List_of_Allied_forces_in_the_Normandy_Campaign "List of Allied
forces in the Normandy Campaign").

  * [British 6th Airborne Division](/wiki/6th_Airborne_Division_\(United_Kingdom\) "6th Airborne Division \(United Kingdom\)").[18]
  * [British I Corps](/wiki/I_Corps_\(United_Kingdom\) "I Corps \(United Kingdom\)"), [3rd British Infantry Division](/wiki/3rd_Division_\(United_Kingdom\) "3rd Division \(United Kingdom\)") and the [British 27th Armoured Brigade](/wiki/27th_Armoured_Brigade "27th Armoured Brigade").
  * [3rd Canadian Infantry Division](/wiki/3rd_Canadian_Division "3rd Canadian Division"), [2nd Canadian Armoured Brigade](/wiki/2nd_Canadian_Armoured_Brigade "2nd Canadian Armoured Brigade")
  * [British XXX Corps](/wiki/XXX_Corps_\(United_Kingdom\) "XXX Corps \(United Kingdom\)"), [British 50th Infantry Division](/wiki/50th_\(Northumbrian\)_Infantry_Division "50th \(Northumbrian\) Infantry Division") and [British 8th Armoured Brigade](/wiki/8th_Armoured_Brigade_\(United_Kingdom\) "8th Armoured Brigade \(United Kingdom\)").[19]
  * [British 79th Armoured Division](/wiki/79th_Armoured_Division_\(United_Kingdom\) "79th Armoured Division \(United Kingdom\)")
  * [U.S. V Corps](/wiki/V_Corps_\(United_States\) "V Corps \(United States\)"), [U.S. 1st Infantry Division](/wiki/1st_Infantry_Division_\(United_States\) "1st Infantry Division \(United States\)") and [U.S. 29th Infantry Division](/wiki/29th_Infantry_Division_\(United_States\) "29th Infantry Division \(United States\)").[18][20]
  * [U.S. VII Corps](/wiki/VII_Corps_\(United_States\) "VII Corps \(United States\)"), [U.S. 4th Infantry Division](/wiki/4th_Infantry_Division_\(United_States\) "4th Infantry Division \(United States\)"),[20] [U.S. 101st Airborne Division](/wiki/101st_Airborne_Division "101st Airborne Division"),[20] [U.S. 82nd Airborne Division](/wiki/82nd_Airborne_Division "82nd Airborne Division").[20][21][22]

The total number of troops landed on D-Day was around 130,000[23]–156,000[24]
roughly half American and the other from the Commonwealth Realms.

days[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=5

Main article: [Mulberry harbour](/wiki/Mulberry_harbour "Mulberry harbour")

Off Omaha Beach, American Liberty ships – ['Corn
Cobs'](/wiki/Mulberry_harbour#Corn_cob "Mulberry harbour") were scuttled to
provide a makeshift breakwater during the early days of the invasion.

The total troops, vehicles and supplies landed over the period of the invasion
were:

  * By the end of 11 June (D + 5), 326,547 troops, 54,186 vehicles and 104,428 tons of supplies.[24]
  * By 30 June (D+24) over 850,000 men, 148,000 vehicles, and 570,000 tons of supplies.[23]
  * By 4 July one million men had been landed.[25]

### Naval
participants[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Naval participants")]

Main article: [Normandy landings](/wiki/Normandy_landings "Normandy landings")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Lci-convoy.jpg/220px-
Lci-convoy.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lci-convoy.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lci-convoy.jpg "Enlarge")

Large landing craft convoy crosses the English Channel on 6 June 1944.

The invasion fleet was drawn from eight different navies, comprising 6,939
vessels: 1,213 warships, 4,126 transport vessels (landing ships and [landing
craft](/wiki/Landing_craft "Landing craft")), and 736 ancillary craft and 864
merchant vessels.[18]

The overall commander of the Allied Naval Expeditionary Force, providing close
protection and bombardment at the beaches, was Admiral Sir Bertram Ramsay. The
Allied Naval Expeditionary Force was divided into two Naval Task Forces:
Western (Rear-Admiral [Alan G Kirk](/wiki/Alan_G_Kirk "Alan G Kirk")) and
Eastern (Rear-Admiral Sir [Philip Vian](/wiki/Philip_Vian "Philip Vian")).

The warships provided cover for the transports against the enemy—whether in
the form of surface [warships](/wiki/Warship "Warship"),
[submarines](/wiki/Submarine "Submarine"), or as an aerial attack—and gave
support to the landings through shore bombardment. These ships included the
Allied Task Force "O".

## German order of
battle[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: German order of battle")]

The number of military forces at the disposal of Nazi Germany reached its peak
during 1944. Tanks on the east front peaked at 5,202 in November 1944, while
total aircraft in the Luftwaffe inventory peaked at 5,041 in December 1944. By
D-Day 157 German divisions were stationed in the Soviet Union, 6 in Finland,
12 in Norway, 6 in Denmark, 9 in Germany, 21 in the Balkans, 26 in Italy and
59 in France, Belgium and the Netherlands.[26] However, these statistics are
somewhat misleading since a significant number of the divisions in the east
were depleted; German records indicate that the average personnel complement
was at about 50% in the spring of 1944.[27]

A more detailed order of battle for D-Day itself can be found at [Normandy
landings](/wiki/Normandy_landings "Normandy landings").

Wall[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Atlantic Wall")]

Main articles: [Atlantic Wall](/wiki/Atlantic_Wall "Atlantic Wall") and
[English Channel § Second World War](/wiki/English_Channel#Second_World_War

Atlantikwall.png)](/wiki/File:Atlantikwall.png)

[](/wiki/File:Atlantikwall.png "Enlarge")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-364-2314-16A%2C_Atlantikwall%2C_Batterie_%22Lindemann%22.jpg/220px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-364-2314-16A%2C_Atlantikwall%2C_Batterie_%22Lindemann%22.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-364-2314-16A,_Atlantikwall,_Batterie_%22Lindemann%22.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-364-2314-16A,_Atlantikwall,_Batterie_%22Lindemann%22.jpg
"Enlarge")

German [Cross-Channel gun](/wiki/Cross-Channel_guns_in_the_Second_World_War
"Cross-Channel guns in the Second World War") of the Atlantic Wall. One of
three [40.6cm guns](/wiki/Adolf_Gun "Adolf Gun") at Batterie "Lindemann"

Standing in the way of the Allies was the [English
Channel](/wiki/English_Channel "English Channel"), an obstacle that had
frustrated the ambitions of the [Spanish Armada](/wiki/Spanish_Armada "Spanish
Armada") and [Napoleon Bonaparte](/wiki/Napoleon_Bonaparte "Napoleon
Bonaparte")'s Navy. Compounding the difficulty of invasion was the extensive
[Atlantic Wall](/wiki/Atlantic_Wall "Atlantic Wall"), ordered by
[Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") in his Directive 51. Believing
that any forthcoming landings would be timed for high tide (this caused the
landings to be timed for low tide), Hitler had the entire wall fortified with
tank top turrets and extensive barbed wire, and laid a million mines to deter
landing craft.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The sector that was attacked was guarded by
four divisions.

#### Divisional
areas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Divisional areas")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-731-0388-20%2C_Frankreich%2C_nach_der_Invasion%2C_Infanteristen.jpg/220px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-731-0388-20%2C_Frankreich%2C_nach_der_Invasion%2C_Infanteristen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-731-0388-20,_Frankreich,_nach_der_Invasion,_Infanteristen.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-731-0388-20,_Frankreich,_nach_der_Invasion,_Infanteristen.jpg
"Enlarge")

German infantrymen scan the skies for Allied aircraft in Normandy, 1944

The following units were deployed in a static defensive mode in the areas of
the actual landings:

  * [716th Infantry Division (Static)](/wiki/German_716th_Static_Infantry_Division "German 716th Static Infantry Division") consisted mainly of those 'unfit for active duty' and released prisoners.
  * [352nd Infantry Division](/wiki/German_352nd_Infantry_Division "German 352nd Infantry Division"), a well-trained unit containing combat veterans.
  * [91st Air Landing Division](/wiki/German_91st_Infantry_Division "German 91st Infantry Division") (_Luftlande_ – air transported), a regular infantry division, trained, and equipped to be transported by air.
  * [709th Infantry Division (Static)](/wiki/German_709th_Static_Infantry_Division "German 709th Static Infantry Division"). Like the 716th, this division included a number of "[Ost](/wiki/Ostlegionen "Ostlegionen")" battalions led by German personnel.

#### Adjacent divisional
areas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Adjacent divisional areas")]

Other divisions occupied the areas around the landing zones, including:

  * [243rd Infantry Division (Static)](/wiki/German_243rd_Static_Infantry_Division "German 243rd Static Infantry Division"), (Generalleutnant [Heinz Hellmich](/wiki/Heinz_Hellmich "Heinz Hellmich")). This coastal defense division protected the western coast of the [Cotentin Peninsula](/wiki/Cotentin_Peninsula "Cotentin Peninsula"). 
    * 920th Infantry Regiment (two battalions)
    * 921st Infantry Regiment
    * 922nd Infantry Regiment.
  * [711th Infantry Division (Static)](/wiki/711th_Infantry_Division_\(Wehrmacht\) "711th Infantry Division \(Wehrmacht\)") (Generalleutnant [Josef Reichert](/wiki/Josef_Reichert "Josef Reichert")). This division defended the western part of the [Pays de Caux](/wiki/Pays_de_Caux "Pays de Caux"). 
    * 731st Infantry Regiment
    * 744th Infantry Regiment.
  * 30th Mobile Brigade (Oberstleutnant Freiherr von und zu Aufsess), comprising three [bicycle](/wiki/Bicycle_infantry "Bicycle infantry") battalions.

### Armoured
reserves[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Armoured reserves")]

Rommel's defensive measures were frustrated by a dispute over armoured
doctrine. In addition to his two army groups, Rundstedt also commanded the
headquarters of _Panzer Group West_ under General [Leo Geyr von
Schweppenburg](/wiki/Leo_Geyr_von_Schweppenburg "Leo Geyr von Schweppenburg")
(usually referred to as "von Geyr"). This formation was nominally an
administrative HQ for Rundstedt's armoured and mobile formations, but it was
later to be brought into the line in Normandy and renamed [Fifth Panzer
Army](/wiki/5th_Panzer_Army "5th Panzer Army"). Geyr and Rommel disagreed over
the deployment and use of the vital Panzer divisions.

Rommel recognised that the Allies would possess air superiority and would be
able to harass his movements from the air. He therefore proposed that the
armoured formations be deployed close to the invasion beaches. In his words,
it was better to have one Panzer division facing the invaders on the first
day, than three Panzer divisions three days later when the Allies would
already have established a firm beachhead. Geyr argued for the standard
doctrine that the Panzer formations should be concentrated in a central
position around Paris and Rouen, and deployed _en masse_ against the main
Allied beachhead when this had been identified.

The argument was eventually brought before Hitler for arbitration. He
characteristically imposed an unworkable compromise solution. Only three
Panzer divisions were given to Rommel, too few to cover all the threatened
sectors. The remainder, nominally under Geyr's control, were actually
designated as being in "[OKW](/wiki/Oberkommando_der_Wehrmacht "Oberkommando
der Wehrmacht") Reserve". Only three of these were deployed close enough to
intervene immediately against any invasion of Northern France; the other four
were dispersed in southern France and the Netherlands. Hitler reserved to
himself the authority to move the divisions in OKW Reserve, or commit them to
action. On 6 June many Panzer division commanders were unable to move because
Hitler had not given the necessary authorisation, and his staff refused to
wake him upon news of the invasion.

#### Army Group B
reserve[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Army Group B reserve")]

  * [21st Panzer Division](/wiki/German_21st_Panzer_Division "German 21st Panzer Division") (Generalmajor [Edgar Feuchtinger](/wiki/Edgar_Feuchtinger "Edgar Feuchtinger")), was deployed near [Caen](/wiki/Caen "Caen") as a mobile striking force as part of the [Army Group B](/wiki/Army_Group_B "Army Group B") reserve. However, Rommel placed it so close to the coastal defenses that, under [standing orders](/wiki/General_order "General order") in case of invasion, several of its infantry and anti-aircraft units would come under the orders of the fortress divisions on the coast, reducing the effective strength of the division.

The other two armoured divisions over which Rommel had operational control,
the [2nd Panzer Division](/wiki/2nd_Panzer_Division_\(Wehrmacht\) "2nd Panzer
Division \(Wehrmacht\)") and [116th Panzer
Division](/wiki/116th_Panzer_Division_\(Wehrmacht\) "116th Panzer Division
\(Wehrmacht\)"), were deployed near the Pas de Calais in accordance with
German views about the likely Allied landing sites. Neither was moved from the
Pas de Calais for at least fourteen days after the invasion.

#### OKW
reserve[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: OKW reserve")]

The other mechanized divisions capable of intervening in Normandy were
retained under the direct control of the German Armed Forces HQ
([OKW](/wiki/OKW "OKW")) and were initially denied to Rommel:

Four divisions were deployed to Normandy within seven days of the invasion:

  * [12th SS Panzer Division Hitlerjugend](/wiki/12th_SS_Panzer_Division_Hitlerjugend "12th SS Panzer Division Hitlerjugend") (Brigadeführer [Fritz Witt](/wiki/Fritz_Witt "Fritz Witt")) was stationed to the southeast. Its officers and [NCOs](/wiki/NCOs "NCOs") (this division had a very weak core of NCOs in Normandy with only slightly more than 50% of its authorised strength[28]) were long-serving veterans, but the junior soldiers had all been recruited directly from the [Hitler Youth](/wiki/Hitler_Youth "Hitler Youth") movement at the age of seventeen in 1943. It was to acquire a reputation for ferocity and war crimes in the coming battle.
  * [Panzer-Lehr-Division](/wiki/Panzer-Lehr-Division "Panzer-Lehr-Division") (Generalmajor [Fritz Bayerlein](/wiki/Fritz_Bayerlein "Fritz Bayerlein")). Further to the southwest was an elite unit, originally formed by amalgamating the instructing staff at various training establishments. Not only were its personnel of high quality, but the division also had unusually high numbers of the latest and most capable armoured vehicles.
  * [1st SS Panzer Division Leibstandarte SS Adolf Hitler](/wiki/1st_SS_Division_Leibstandarte_SS_Adolf_Hitler "1st SS Division Leibstandarte SS Adolf Hitler") was refitting in Belgium on the Netherlands border after being decimated on the Eastern Front.
  * [17th SS Panzergrenadier Division Götz von Berlichingen](/wiki/17th_SS_Panzergrenadier_Division_G%C3%B6tz_von_Berlichingen "17th SS Panzergrenadier Division Götz von Berlichingen") (Oberführer [Werner Ostendorff](/wiki/Werner_Ostendorff "Werner Ostendorff")) was based on [Thouars](/wiki/Thouars "Thouars"), south of the [Loire River](/wiki/Loire_River "Loire River"), and although equipped with Assault guns instead of tanks and lacking in other transport (such that one battalion each from the 37th and 38th Panzergrenadier Regiments moved by bicycle), it provided the first major counterattack against the American advance at Carentan on 13 June.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/NormandySupply_edit.jpg/220px-
NormandySupply_edit.jpg)](/wiki/File:NormandySupply_edit.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NormandySupply_edit.jpg "Enlarge")

Landing supplies at Normandy

Three other divisions (the [2nd SS Panzer Division Das
Reich](/wiki/2nd_SS_Panzer_Division_Das_Reich "2nd SS Panzer Division Das
Reich"), which had been refitting at [Montauban](/wiki/Montauban "Montauban")
in Southern France, and the [9th SS Panzer Division
Hohenstaufen](/wiki/9th_SS_Panzer_Division_Hohenstaufen "9th SS Panzer
Division Hohenstaufen") and [10th SS Panzer Division
Frundsberg](/wiki/10th_SS_Panzer_Division_Frundsberg "10th SS Panzer Division
Frundsberg") which had been in transit from the Eastern Front on 6 June), were
committed to battle in Normandy around twenty-one days after the first
landings.

One more armoured division (the [9th Panzer
Division](/wiki/9th_Panzer_Division_\(Wehrmacht\) "9th Panzer Division
\(Wehrmacht\)")) saw action only after the American breakout from the
beachhead. Two other armoured divisions which had been in the west on 6 June
(the [11th Panzer Division](/wiki/11th_Panzer_Division_\(Wehrmacht\) "11th
Panzer Division \(Wehrmacht\)") and [19th Panzer
Division](/wiki/19th_Panzer_Division_\(Wehrmacht\) "19th Panzer Division
\(Wehrmacht\)")) did not see action in Normandy.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Normandy7.jpg/220px-
Normandy7.jpg)](/wiki/File:Normandy7.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Normandy7.jpg "Enlarge")

The build-up of Omaha Beach: reinforcements of men and equipment moving inland

## Allied establishment in
France[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Allied establishment in France")]

The Allied invasion plans had called for the capture of [Saint-
Lô](/wiki/Saint-L%C3%B4 "Saint-Lô"), [Caen](/wiki/Caen "Caen"), and
[Bayeux](/wiki/Bayeux "Bayeux") on the first day, with all the beaches linked
except Utah, and Sword (the last linked with paratroopers) and a front line 10
to 16 kilometres (6–10 mi) from the beaches. However, practically none of
these objectives had been achieved. It took six weeks for British and Canadian
troops to capture Caen, as they faced seven Panzer divisions, while their
American allies, although advancing more rapidly, faced only two of these
divisions. Overall the casualties had not been as heavy as some had feared
(around 10,000 compared to the 20,000 Churchill had estimated) and the
bridgeheads had withstood the expected counterattacks.

Once the beachhead was established, two artificial [Mulberry
harbours](/wiki/Mulberry_harbour "Mulberry harbour") were towed across the
English Channel in segments and made operational around D+3 (9 June). One was
constructed at [Arromanches](/wiki/Arromanches "Arromanches") by British
forces, the other at Omaha Beach by American forces. By 19 June, when severe
storms interrupted the landing of supplies for several days and destroyed the
Omaha harbour, the British had landed 314,547 men, 54,000 vehicles, and
102,000 tons of supplies, while the Americans put ashore 314,504 men, 41,000
vehicles, and 116,000 tons of supplies.[29] Around 9,000 tons of
[materiel](/wiki/Materiel "Materiel") were landed daily at the Arromanches
harbour until the end of August 1944, by which time the port of
[Cherbourg](/wiki/Cherbourg-Octeville "Cherbourg-Octeville") had been secured
by the Allies and had begun to return to service.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In addition, with the installation of [PLUTO](/wiki/Operation_Pluto "Operation
Pluto") in August 1944 the Allies had fuel piped over directly from England
without having to rely on vulnerable tankers.

## Assessment of the
battle[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Assessment of the battle")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this section](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(September 2015)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/German_military_cemetery_Normandy_1.jpg/220px-
German_military_cemetery_Normandy_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:German_military_cemetery_Normandy_1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:German_military_cemetery_Normandy_1.jpg "Enlarge")

[La Cambe German war cemetery](/wiki/La_Cambe_German_war_cemetery "La Cambe
German war cemetery")

The [Normandy landings](/wiki/Normandy_landings "Normandy landings") were the
first successful opposed landings across the English Channel in [over eight
centuries](/wiki/Battle_of_Tinchebray "Battle of Tinchebray"). They were
costly in terms of men, but the defeat inflicted on the Germans was one of the
largest of the war. Strategically, the campaign led to the loss of the German
position in most of France and the secure establishment of a new major front.
In larger context the Normandy landings helped the
[Soviets](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") on the [Eastern
Front](/wiki/Eastern_Front_\(World_War_II\) "Eastern Front \(World War II\)"),
who were facing the bulk of the German forces and, to a certain extent,
contributed to the shortening of the conflict there.

Although there was a shortage of artillery ammunition, at no time were the
Allies critically short of any necessity. This was a remarkable achievement
considering they did not hold a port until Cherbourg fell. By the time of the
breakout the Allies also enjoyed a considerable superiority in numbers of
troops (approximately 7:2) and armoured vehicles (approximately 4:1) which
helped overcome the natural advantages the terrain gave to the German
defenders.

Allied [intelligence and counterintelligence](/wiki/Espionage "Espionage")
efforts were successful beyond expectations. The Operation Fortitude deception
before the invasion kept German attention focused on the Pas de Calais, and
indeed high-quality German forces were kept in this area, away from Normandy,
until July. Prior to the invasion, few German reconnaissance flights took
place over Britain, and those that did saw only the dummy staging areas.
[Ultra](/wiki/Ultra "Ultra") decrypts of German communications had been
helpful as well, exposing German dispositions and revealing their plans such
as the [Mortain counterattack](/wiki/Operation_L%C3%BCttich "Operation
Lüttich").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/The_British_Army_in_Normandy_1944_B6934.jpg/220px-
The_British_Army_in_Normandy_1944_B6934.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_British_Army_in_Normandy_1944_B6934.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_British_Army_in_Normandy_1944_B6934.jpg "Enlarge")

[General](/wiki/General_\(United_Kingdom\) "General \(United Kingdom\)")
[Bernard
Montgomery](/wiki/Bernard_Montgomery,_1st_Viscount_Montgomery_of_Alamein
"Bernard Montgomery, 1st Viscount Montgomery of Alamein") with British troops
in Normandy, July 1944

Allied air operations also contributed significantly to the invasion, via
close tactical support, interdiction of German lines of communication
(preventing timely movement of supplies and reinforcements—particularly the
critical Panzer units), and rendering the [Luftwaffe](/wiki/Luftwaffe
"Luftwaffe") ineffective in Normandy.[nb 2] Although the impact upon armoured
vehicles was less than expected, air activity intimidated these units and cut
their supplies.

Despite initial heavy losses in the assault phase, Allied morale remained
high. Casualty rates among all the armies were tremendous, and the
Commonwealth forces had to use a recently created category—Double Intense—to
be able to describe them.

### German
leadership[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: German leadership")]

German commanders at all levels failed to react to the assault phase in a
timely manner. Communications problems exacerbated the difficulties caused by
Allied air and naval firepower. Local commanders also seemed incapable of the
task of fighting an aggressive defense on the beach, as Rommel had envisioned.

The German High Command remained fixated on the Calais area, and von Rundstedt
was not permitted to commit the armoured reserve. When it was finally released
late in the day, its chance of success was greatly reduced. Overall, despite
considerable Allied material superiority, the Germans kept the Allies bottled
up in a small beachhead for nearly two months, aided immeasurably by terrain
factors.

Although there were several known disputes among the Allied commanders, their
tactics and strategy were essentially determined by agreement among the main
commanders. By contrast, the German leaders were bullied and their decisions
interfered with by OKW. Field Marshals von Rundstedt and Rommel repeatedly
asked Hitler for more discretion but were refused. Rundstedt was removed from
his command on 29 June after he bluntly told the Chief of Staff at Hitler's
Armed Forces HQ (Field Marshal [Keitel](/wiki/Wilhelm_Keitel "Wilhelm
Keitel")) to "Make peace, you idiots!" Rommel was severely injured by Allied
aircraft on 17 July.

Sixty thousand of the 850,000 in Rundstedt's command were raised from the many
prisoners of war taken on the Eastern Front.[30] Many surrendered or deserted
at the first available opportunity.

## War memorials and
tourism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: War memorials and tourism")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Beny-sur-
Mer_Cemetery.jpg/685px-Beny-sur-Mer_Cemetery.jpg)](/wiki/File:Beny-sur-
Mer_Cemetery.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Beny-sur-Mer_Cemetery.jpg "File:Beny-sur-Mer Cemetery.jpg")

The [Bény-sur-Mer Canadian War Cemetery](/wiki/B%C3%A9ny-sur-
Mer_Canadian_War_Cemetery "Bény-sur-Mer Canadian War Cemetery")

The beaches at Normandy are still referred to on maps and signposts by their
invasion codenames. There are several vast [cemeteries](/wiki/Cemetery
"Cemetery") in the area. The [American
cemetery](/wiki/Normandy_American_Cemetery_and_Memorial "Normandy American
Cemetery and Memorial"), in [Colleville-sur-Mer](/wiki/Colleville-sur-Mer
"Colleville-sur-Mer"), contains row upon row of identical white
[crosses](/wiki/Christian_cross "Christian cross") and [Stars of
David](/wiki/Star_of_David "Star of David"), immaculately kept, commemorating
the American dead. [Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth
of Nations") graves, maintained in many locations by the [Commonwealth War
Graves Commission](/wiki/Commonwealth_War_Graves_Commission "Commonwealth War
Graves Commission"), uses white headstones engraved with the person's
religious or medal ([Victoria Cross](/wiki/Victoria_Cross "Victoria Cross") or
[George Cross](/wiki/George_Cross "George Cross") only) symbol and their unit
insignia. The [Bayeux War Cemetery](/wiki/Bayeux_War_Cemetery "Bayeux War
Cemetery"), with 4,648 burials, is the largest British cemetery of the
war.[31] The largest cemetery in Normandy is the [La Cambe German war
cemetery](/wiki/La_Cambe_German_war_cemetery "La Cambe German war cemetery"),
with 21,222 burials, which features granite stones almost flush with the
ground and groups of low-set crosses. There is also a Polish cemetery.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Stmereeglise.jpg/170px-
Stmereeglise.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stmereeglise.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stmereeglise.jpg "Enlarge")

Paratroop memorial in [Sainte-Mère-Église](/wiki/Sainte-M%C3%A8re-%C3%89glise
"Sainte-Mère-Église")

At the Bayeux Memorial, a monument erected by Britain has a Latin inscription
on the memorial reads "_Nos a gulielmo victi victoris patriam liberavimus_ " –
freely translated, this reads "We, once conquered by
[William](/wiki/William_I_of_England "William I of England"), have now set
free the Conqueror's native land".[31]

Streets near the beaches are still named after the units that fought there,
and occasional markers commemorate notable incidents. At significant points,
such as [Pointe du Hoc](/wiki/Pointe_du_Hoc "Pointe du Hoc") and [Pegasus
Bridge](/wiki/Pegasus_Bridge "Pegasus Bridge"), there are plaques, memorials
or small museums. The Mulberry harbour still sits in the sea at
[Arromanches](/wiki/Arromanches "Arromanches"). In [Sainte-Mère-
Église](/wiki/Sainte-M%C3%A8re-%C3%89glise "Sainte-Mère-Église"), a dummy
paratrooper hangs from the church spire. On Juno Beach, the Canadian
government has built the [Juno Beach Information
Centre](/wiki/Juno_Beach_Centre "Juno Beach Centre"), commemorating one of the
most significant events in Canadian military history.

In England the most significant memorial is the [D-Day
Museum](/wiki/D-Day_Museum "D-Day Museum") in Southsea, Hampshire. The Museum
was opened in 1984 to commemorate the 40th anniversary of D-Day. Its
centrepiece is the [Overlord embroidery](/wiki/Overlord_embroidery "Overlord
embroidery") commissioned by Lord Dulverton of Batsford (1915–92) as a tribute
to the sacrifice and heroism of those men and women who took part in Operation
Overlord.

On 5 June 1994 a drumhead service was held on Southsea Common adjacent the
D-Day Museum. This service was attended by US President [Bill
Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton"), [Queen Elizabeth
II](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II "Queen Elizabeth II") and over 100,000 members of
the public.

##
Dramatisations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Invasion_of_Normandy&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Dramatisations")]

The Battle of Normandy has been the topic of many films, television shows,
songs, computer games and books. Many dramatisations focus on the initial
landings, and these are covered at [Normandy Landings](/wiki/Normandy_Landings
"Normandy Landings"). Some examples that cover the wider battle include:

Films

  * _[Le Bataillon du ciel](/w/index.php?title=Le_Bataillon_du_ciel&action=edit&redlink=1 "Le Bataillon du ciel \(page does not exist\)")_ (sky's battalion), a 1947 French film directed by Alexandre Esway based on the book of [Joseph Kessel](/wiki/Joseph_Kessel "Joseph Kessel"): Free French SAS paratroopers ([Special Air Service](/wiki/Special_Air_Service "Special Air Service")) in Brittany from 5 June to August 1944.
  * _[The Longest Day](/wiki/The_Longest_Day_\(film\) "The Longest Day \(film\)")_ , a 1962 film based on the [book](/wiki/The_Longest_Day_\(book\) "The Longest Day \(book\)") of the same name by [Cornelius Ryan](/wiki/Cornelius_Ryan "Cornelius Ryan")
  * _[The Americanization of Emily](/wiki/The_Americanization_of_Emily "The Americanization of Emily")_ , a 1964 film written by [Paddy Chayefsky](/wiki/Paddy_Chayefsky "Paddy Chayefsky"), directed by [Arthur Hiller](/wiki/Arthur_Hiller "Arthur Hiller") and starring [James Garner](/wiki/James_Garner "James Garner") and [Julie Andrews](/wiki/Julie_Andrews "Julie Andrews").
  * _[Overlord](/wiki/Overlord_\(film\) "Overlord \(film\)")_ , a 1975 black-and-white film written and directed by [Stuart Cooper](/wiki/Stuart_Cooper "Stuart Cooper"), set around the D-Day invasion.
  * _[The Big Red One](/wiki/The_Big_Red_One "The Big Red One")_ , a 1980 film directed by [Samuel Fuller](/wiki/Samuel_Fuller "Samuel Fuller") and starring [Lee Marvin](/wiki/Lee_Marvin "Lee Marvin").
  * _[Un jour avant l'aube](/w/index.php?title=Un_jour_avant_l%27aube&action=edit&redlink=1 "Un jour avant l'aube \(page does not exist\)")_ (One day before dawn), a 1994 French television film directed by Jacques Ertaud: Free French SAS in Brittany.
  * _[Saving Private Ryan](/wiki/Saving_Private_Ryan "Saving Private Ryan")_ , a 1998 Academy Award-winning American film directed by [Steven Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven Spielberg") and starring [Tom Hanks](/wiki/Tom_Hanks "Tom Hanks") and [Matt Damon](/wiki/Matt_Damon "Matt Damon").
  * _[Band of Brothers](/wiki/Band_of_Brothers_\(TV_miniseries\) "Band of Brothers \(TV miniseries\)")_ , a 2001 American [miniseries](/wiki/Miniseries "Miniseries") produced by Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks based on the book of the same name by [Stephen Ambrose](/wiki/Stephen_Ambrose "Stephen Ambrose").
  * _[Ike: Countdown to D-Day](/wiki/Ike:_Countdown_to_D-Day "Ike: Countdown to D-Day")_ , a 2004 American television film directed by [Robert Harmon](/wiki/Robert_Harmon "Robert Harmon") and written by [Lionel Chetwynd](/wiki/Lionel_Chetwynd "Lionel Chetwynd") which emphasizes the difficult decisions General [Dwight D. Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight D. Eisenhower") had to make, while dealing with the varied personalities of his direct subordinates, in order to lead Operation Overlord.
  * _[My Way](/wiki/My_Way_\(2011_film\) "My Way \(2011 film\)")_ , a 2011 South Korean war film by [Kang Je-gyu](/wiki/Kang_Je-gyu "Kang Je-gyu"), starring [Jang Dong-gun](/wiki/Jang_Dong-gun "Jang Dong-gun") along with Japanese actor [Joe Odagiri](/wiki/Joe_Odagiri "Joe Odagiri") and Chinese actress [Fan Bingbing](/wiki/Fan_Bingbing "Fan Bingbing").

  * Numerous volumes in _the U.S. Army in World War II_ series, produced by the [United States Army Center of Military History](/wiki/United_States_Army_Center_of_Military_History "United States Army Center of Military History"), Gordon A. Harrison, _[Cross-Channel-Attack](http://www.history.army.mil/books/wwii/7-4/7-4_Contents.htm)_ (1951), remains a basic source, but several other studies bear heavily upon the operation. They include:

  1. Robert W. Coakley and Richard M. Leighton, _Global Logistics and Strategy_ (1968);
  2. [Martin Blumenson](/wiki/Martin_Blumenson "Martin Blumenson"), _Breakout and Pursuit_ (1961);
  3. Forrest C. Pogue, _The Supreme Command_ (1954);
  4. Roland G. Ruppenthal, _Logistical Support of the Armies_ (1953); and
  5. Graham A. Cosmas and **Albert E. Cowdrey** , _The Medical Department: Medical Service in the European Theater of Operations_ (1992).

  * The Historical Division of the War Department produced three volumes on the event. All have been reprinted by the Center of Military History. Classified as **the American Forces in Action** series, they are:

  1. _[OMAHA Beachhead](http://www.history.army.mil/books/wwii/100-11/100-11.htm)_ (1989);
  2. _[UTAH Beach to Cherbourg](http://www.history.army.mil/books/wwii/utah/utah.htm)_ (1990); and
  3. _St. Lo_ (1984).

  * The British Government following the war also issued an official history of the British involvement in the war to be researched and published, the final result being the massive series known as **[History of the Second World War](/wiki/History_of_the_Second_World_War "History of the Second World War")**. The following cover the Normandy Campaign:

  1. [Major L. F. Ellis](/wiki/Lionel_Ellis "Lionel Ellis"), _Victory in the West: The Battle of Normandy, Official Campaign History v. I_ (History of the Second World War: United Kingdom Military), Naval & Military Press Ltd; New Ed edition (Sep 2004)., 1-84574-058-0
  2. [Michael Howard](/wiki/Michael_Howard_\(historian\) "Michael Howard \(historian\)"), _British Intelligence in the Second World War: Volume 5, Strategic Deception_ , Cambridge University Press (26 October 1990). [ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International Standard Book Number") [0-521-40145-3](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-521-40145-3 "Special:BookSources/0-521-40145-3") (Series edited by [F. H. Hinsley](/wiki/Harry_Hinsley "Harry Hinsley"))
  3. _Grand Strategy, Volume 5: August 1943 – September 1944_ , 1956

  * Numerous abbreviated histories have been written. Among the most useful are:

  1. Charles MacDonald, _The Mighty Endeavor: American Armed Forces in the European Theater in World War II_ (1969); and
  2. Charles MacDonald and Martin Blumenson, "Recovery of France", in Vincent J. Esposito, ed., _A Concise History of World War II_ (1965).

  * Memoirs by Allied commanders contain considerable information. Among the best are:

  1. [Omar N. Bradley](/wiki/Omar_N._Bradley "Omar N. Bradley"), _A Soldier 's Story_ (1951);
  2. Omar N. Bradley and Clay Blair, _A General 's Life_ (1983);
  3. [Dwight D. Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight D. Eisenhower"), _Crusade in Europe_ (1948);
  4. Sir Bernard Law Montgomery of Alamein, _Normandy to the Baltic_ (1948);
  5. Sir Bernard Law Montgomery of Alamein, The Memoirs of Field Marshal the Viscount Montgomery of Alamein, K.G., Collins (1958). and
  6. Sir Frederick Edgeworth Morgan, _Overture to Overlord_ (1950).

  * Memoirs by Allied and German soldiers of various ranks also give a good insight into the campaign.

  1. Kurt Meyer, _Grenadiers_ , Stackpole Books, U.S., New Ed edition (15 May 2005)., [ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International Standard Book Number") [0-8117-3197-9](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-8117-3197-9 "Special:BookSources/0-8117-3197-9")
  2. Stuart Hills, _By Tank Into Normandy_ , Cassell military; New Ed edition (11 September 2003)., 0-30436-640-4
  3. [Hans von Luck](/wiki/Hans_von_Luck "Hans von Luck"), Panzer Commander: The Memoirs of Colonel Hans von Luck, Cassell military; New Ed edition (9 March 2006)., [ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International Standard Book Number") [0-304-36401-0](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-304-36401-0 "Special:BookSources/0-304-36401-0")

  * Almost as useful are biographies of leading commanders. Among the most prominent are:

  1. Stephen E. Ambrose, _The Supreme Commander: The War Years of General Dwight D. Eisenhower_ (1970), and _Eisenhower, Soldier, General of the Army, President-Elect, 1890–1952_ (1983);
  2. Nigel Hamilton, _Master of the Battlefield: Monty 's War Years, 1942–1944_ (1983);
  3. Richard Lamb, _Montgomery in Europe, 1943–1945: Success or Failure_ (1984);
  4. Nigel Hamilton, "Montgomery, Bernard Law" in _[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography](/wiki/Dictionary_of_National_Biography "Dictionary of National Biography")_. Oxford; New York: Oxford University Press, 2004. [ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International Standard Book Number") [0-19-861411-X](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-19-861411-X "Special:BookSources/0-19-861411-X"), [ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International Standard Book Number") [0-19-861351-2](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-19-861351-2 "Special:BookSources/0-19-861351-2").
  5. [Ronald Lewin](/wiki/Ronald_Lewin "Ronald Lewin"), _Rommel as Military Commander_ (1968).
  6. [B. H. Liddell Hart](/wiki/B._H._Liddell_Hart "B. H. Liddell Hart"), _The Rommel Papers_ (section on Normandy written by Lt.Gen [Fritz Bayerlein](/wiki/Fritz_Bayerlein "Fritz Bayerlein"))
  7. Hans Speidel, _Invasion 1944: Rommel and the Normandy Campaign_. Chicago: Henry Regnery (1950) ([Speidel](/wiki/Hans_Speidel "Hans Speidel") was Rommel's chief of staff).

  * Numerous general histories also exist, many centering on the controversies that continue to surround the campaign and its commanders:

  1. John Colby, _War From the Ground Up: The 90th Division in World War II_ (1989);
  2. Carlo D'Este, _Decision in Normandy: The Unwritten Story of Montgomery and the Allied Campaign_ (1983);
  3. [Max Hastings](/wiki/Max_Hastings "Max Hastings"), _Overlord, D-Day, June 6, 1944_ (1984);
  4. [John Keegan](/wiki/John_Keegan "John Keegan"), _Six Armies in Normandy: From D-Day to the Liberation of Paris_ (1982);
  5. [Robin Neillands](/wiki/Robin_Neillands "Robin Neillands"), _The Battle of Normandy 1944_ (2002);
  6. Stephen T. Powers, "Battle of Normandy: The Lingering Controversy", _Journal of Military History_ 56 (1992):455–71.
  7. Russell F. Weigley, _Eisenhower 's Lieutenants: The Campaign of France and Germany, 1944–45_ (1981);
  8. [Cornelius Ryan](/wiki/Cornelius_Ryan "Cornelius Ryan"), _The Longest Day '_, (1959);
  9. Stephen Ambrose, _D-Day: June 6, 1944, The Battle for the Normandy Beaches_ , (1994);
  10. [Milton Shulman](/wiki/Milton_Shulman "Milton Shulman"), _Defeat in the West_ , (New Ed edition 2003)
  11. Richard Holmes, _The D-Day Experience: From the Invasion to the Liberation of Paris with Other and Map and CD_ ,(2004);
  12. [Chester Wilmot](/wiki/Chester_Wilmot "Chester Wilmot"), _The Struggle for Europe_ , (New Ed edition 1997), and
  13. Stephen Ashley Hart, _Colossal Cracks: Montgomery 's 21st Army Group in Northwest Europe, 1944–45_, (2007)

  * Journalists were among the foremost observers of the invasion:

  1. Barney Oldfield, _Never a Shot in Anger_ (1956); and
  2. Richard Collier, _Fighting Words: The Correspondents of World War II_ (1989). CMH Pub 72–18
